image.altText: people carry someone on a stretcher while stepping through debris

props.synopsis: After the collapse of the week-long truce, fighting resumes, with Israeli warplanes pounding Gaza and Hamas sending rockets from the enclave into nearby towns.

title.children: Gaza health ministry says more than 170 people killed in Israeli strikes after ceasefire ends

image.altText: A hand holding three tobacconist leaflets.

props.synopsis: SA Health is looking into complaints of unlicensed tobacco stores in Adelaide, as leaflets advertising cheap cigarettes were found in suburban letterboxes.

title.children: Health authorities investigating multiple complaints of unlicensed tobacco stores

image.altText: Former digger Keith Fowler with the street named after him.

props.synopsis: Mr Fowler was the last surviving member of his machine gun battalion and was one of more than 22,000 Australians taken prisoner by the Japanese.

title.children: World War II veteran Keith Fowler dies at 103

image.altText: An image of Brittany Higgins next to an image of Bruce Lehrmann.

props.synopsis: Brittany Higgins's allegation she was raped by former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann in then-minister Linda Reynolds's office has had far-reaching consequences, and perhaps the most extraordinary part of the tale has been playing out in Federal Court this week.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann's defamation action was set to be a re-run of his trial, but some key evidence is unravelling

image.altText: An elderly man in a blue suit, white shirt, red tie, looks on with a neutral expression

props.synopsis: A US judge rules Donald Trump is not immune from prosecution in his election interference case finding there is no legal basis for concluding that US presidents cannot face criminal charges once they are no longer in office.

title.children: Judge rejects Trump's claim of immunity in election interference case

image.altText: a close-up of an aboriginal man in army uniform looking at camera

props.synopsis: In an era of spy satellites and nuclear submarines, Australia's vast northern borders are still being defended by squadrons of soldiers using techniques that are thousands of years old.

title.children: From a secret location in the Top End, these soldiers use ancient techniques to defend Australia

image.altText: A Matildas striker crouches low to the ground as she runs away from goal with arms spread, as teammates celebrate a goal.

props.synopsis: After bundling them out of the 2023 Women's World Cup group stage, the Matildas are now on the Canadians' turf to close out this remarkable year in style.

title.children: Matildas face Canada in first of two December friendlies

image.altText: close up of george santos smiling walking out of capitol building

props.synopsis: Just before his fate was sealed by a history-making vote to expel him from congress, the New York Republican found himself at the centre of another shocking allegation.

title.children: 'To hell with this place': Congress conman George Santos ousted in historic vote after Republicans turn on their own

image.altText: Man in black shirt hugging his mum, lady in jeans with colourful top, packing up gear in front of grey tent and trailer

props.synopsis: Kristy and Matt Turner were forced to move earlier this year when the owners of the house they were renting moved back in. It happened at a time when dozens of state housing homes sat empty in their regional South Australian town.

title.children: Mother and son finally find somewhere to rent after 70 days living in a tent – but it's four hours from home

image.altText: Female cricketer Amanda-Jade Wellington bowls a ball during an Adelaide Strikers WBBL match

props.synopsis: Adelaide Strikers bowler Amanda-Jade Wellington is expected to be a key player in tonight's Women's Big Bash League final, but she hasn't been able to get a spot in the national team.

title.children: Adelaide Strikers leg spinner pushes for national selection

image.altText: Turtle with bug on its mouth

props.synopsis: Two Australian photographers were chosen from 50,000 entries to make it to the People's Choice shortlist.

title.children: Wildlife Photographer of the Year 2023: Fighting crabs and friendly turtles round out People's Choice finalists

image.altText: A blue, purple, green and red coloured bird feeding two baby birds, perched in a tree.

props.synopsis: With its soft, twittering tune and brilliantly bright plumage, the scarlet-chested parrot is one of Australia's rarely sighted birds that is rejoicing in recent rain in South Australia's Riverland.

title.children: 'Game-changing' downpour provides feast for rare birds

image.altText: A woman with a trolley stands in a stocked supermarket aisle.

props.synopsis: The product feels lighter, or it's smaller, and you can't quite put your finger on the change… but there is a change. Shrinkflation is becoming more widespread, but can anything be done about it, asks David Taylor.

title.children: 'Shrinkflation' is becoming more widespread, but there's one thing shoppers can do to avoid it

image.altText: A young woman wearing red blazer over a white top, stands with arms folded across her chest

props.synopsis: The Kremlin is yet to comment on the alleged poisoning attempt on the wife of Ukraine's chief spy, but if Russian agents are involved, it suggests that Soviet era tactic remains alive and well in the new age of war.

title.children: When the wife of Ukraine's spy chief fell mysteriously ill, she fit into a poisonous new pattern

image.altText: A person wearing a keffiyeh holds their fingers up in a peace sign, a Palestinian flag is in the background.

props.synopsis: What happened in the aftermath of the Sydney Theatre Company performance is a reflection of how the latest conflict in the Middle East has erupted into bitter and dangerous reductionism in political debates in Australia, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: In parliament and in homes, discussion over the Israel-Gaza conflict is reaching a very dangerous tipping point

image.altText: An aerial view of a gas plant on the coast

props.synopsis: Woodside wins approval to carry out seismic testing for its massive Scarborough project off the Pilbara coast after an earlier approval was ruled invalid by the Federal Court.

title.children: Woodside overcomes legal challenges to win approval for seismic blasting off Pilbara coast

image.altText: a composite image one showing a flooded are with trees an looking green the other a sunset after a hot day

props.synopsis: Next week to bring a repeat of wild weather across many parts of Australia, after a surprisingly wet November.

title.children: East Coast Low makes way for severe thunderstorms, a December scorcher, and Coral Sea cyclone

image.altText: four people stand in front of a pub

props.synopsis: Luc Longley and his wife, chef Anna Gare, are part of a group of local investors who have bought the historic Denmark Hotel in Western Australia with plans to renovate the popular watering hole.

title.children: Old pub's new-look reno close to NBA champion Luc Longley's heart

image.altText: A child leans on a scooter while his mother smiles down at him, inside a lift

props.synopsis: The number of no-kids zones in South Korea has exploded in the past decade, but some parents say it's creating a culture where children are unwelcome and restricted from learning how to behave in public.

title.children: 'They just want children who are like dolls': How South Korea's no-kids zones are shifting the culture

image.altText: Cleveland Dodd's casket being carried to his grave.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of mourners gather for the funeral service for the teenager who died inside WA's juvenile detention system.

title.children: Coffin holding Cleveland Dodd's body lowered into the ground on Yamaji country after boy's death in custody

image.altText: A man wearing glasses and a suit and tie.

props.synopsis: Australia's experiment with 'marketisation' of employment services has failed, and we must refocus on helping unemployed people, a new parliamentary report says.

title.children: Why Australia's employment services network needs to stop prioritising profits over people

image.altText: A still capture from a video of courtroom footage showing Derek Chauvin at his sentencing hearing, June 2021.

props.synopsis: The complaint alleges that while incarcerated at Federal Correctional Institution Tucson, John Turscak, 52, stabbed Derek Chauvin about 22 times "with an improvised knife".

title.children: Inmate charged with stabbing George Floyd's killer 22 times

image.altText: An illustration of a wall with rainbow flags and white paper.

props.synopsis: One year on from the "white paper protests", one of the biggest displays of civil disobedience in China since the 1989 Tiananmen massacre, young people are finding creative ways to express political dissent.

title.children: Young Chinese people are finding creative ways keep 'white paper' protest alive

image.altText: Oyster farmers Kelly Jones and Roy Glessing cleaning up their oyster lease

props.synopsis: More than 80 oyster farms on the NSW South Coast remain closed after severe storms and flooding hit this week. It's a flip of the coin as to whether they'll be open in time for Christmas.

title.children: How this week's wild storms might affect your Christmas Day lunch

image.altText: Chris Dawson wearing suit and tie and glasses

props.synopsis: The woman, who cannot be identified for legal reasons, claims she was groomed and sexually abused by the former teacher at a public school on Sydney's northern beaches in the 1970s and 1980s.

title.children: Woman sexually abused by Chris Dawson as a schoolgirl settles lawsuit against New South Wales

image.altText: Sandra Day O'Connor smiling wearing a red jacket.

props.synopsis: Sandra Day O'Connor, whose centrist views and shrewd negotiating skills allowed her to steer the nation's law for much of her quarter-century tenure, dies at the age of 93.

title.children: Sandra Day O'Connor, the first female justice on the US Supreme Court, dies aged 93

image.altText: Ben Dwarshuis is bowled

props.synopsis: India seals the T20 international series after putting Australia in a spin to win the fourth match fairly comfortably in Raipur.

title.children: New-look Australia loses fourth T20 against India

image.altText: Cameron Bancroft holds up his bat

props.synopsis: Cameron Bancroft has put down some serious red ball numbers as the Sheffield Shield heads to its mid-season hibernation, but will it be enough for him to get back into the Test team?

title.children: The numbers that show Cameron Bancroft is in pole position for a Test recall

image.altText: A woman in a black suit and pink shirt with dark hair, is back to back with a man in a black suit and white shirt.

props.synopsis: Islamophobic and antisemitic incidents in Australia are at unprecedented levels as the Israel-Gaza war rages.

title.children: 'Hate attacks, death threats': Unprecedented rise in Islamophobia and anti-Semitism amid Israel-Gaza war

image.altText: A young brown man sitting on the floor with one hand resting on his knee, the other on a red pillow. he's wearing white top

props.synopsis: Oz Malik began devouring films in primary school, but growing up he realised very quickly there were few Muslim men on Western television.

title.children: When Oz Malik watched TV as a kid, Muslim characters were scarce. He's hoping to change that

image.altText: An illustration of a creature on four legs, with a snout like a tapir's.

props.synopsis: Palorchestes was an ancient, blind, sharp-toothed animal that also boasted an elephant-like trunk. It lived for millions of years in pockets of Australia, but its fossils are extremely rare.

title.children: The mysterious creature with 'bizarre' anatomy that once roamed Australia

image.altText: a woman holds a handful of discarded vapes from a bin wearing a high-vis vest

props.synopsis: Disposable vapes are causing a spike in fires at recycling plants with industry experts saying they're battling at least five fires a day in Queensland alone and an increasing risk in other states due to lithium-ion batteries.

title.children: Exploding lithium-ion batteries in disposable vapes are causing five fires a day in Queensland alone

image.altText: A fish swims in a tank

props.synopsis: Researchers find that a simple exercise regime can help fish grow much faster and be more tolerant to disease.

title.children: Why 'bodybuilding fish' could meet the world's growing hunger for seafood

image.altText: A man's hands filling a beer glass at a tap in a brewery.

props.synopsis: Australia's once-booming craft beer industry is navigating troubled waters, with many brewers struggling to stay afloat.

title.children: Is Australia's craft brewing gold rush over, or can the industry bounce back?

image.altText: Pokemon characters on an advert

props.synopsis: A search for the operator of mysterious websites using unlicensed Pokémon branding to spruik an upcoming game has proved trickier than catching the Nintendo characters themselves.

title.children: When Pokémon tried to sue a company purportedly based in Western Sydney, it led to a global search for its operators
